Bright is the eastern sky — Aurora mounts</br>In car dew-dripping, round her snowy breast</br>The rosy radiance plays</br>And sparkles o'er the deep.
Hence, dreary darkness, to the caves of death,</br>Hence, ye fell ghosts, whose fearful shapes have sail'd</br>Across my lonely couch,</br>When blackest midnight reign'd.
Bring me the lyre, and while I strike the chords</br>Strew odorous flowers around — hail!  goddess, hail!</br>Hail to the living ray</br>Which gilds the dusky earth!
For thee the purple violet breathes its sweets,</br>For thee the streaked blossoms fragrant bud,</br>And balmy breezes waft</br>Their grateful scents around;
Nor scorn the suppliant Muse's song of praise,</br>Whose notes of thrilling sound have floated oft</br>Athwart the dark-blue sky,</br>And charm'd the listening gods;
But who, O goddess fairest of thy race,</br>Who, beauteous mother of the shining day,</br>Can praise in equal strains</br>Thy form of heavenly mould?
Before those blushing cheeks, those glittering locks</br>The yellow-twinkling stars abash'd retreat,</br>The fading moon retires</br>And shuns thy splendid step;
From shades of gloomy night thy beams awak'd</br>The mortal race, wide-shooting o'er the land</br>They dy'd with varied light</br>The many-tinted flowers;
Thou, goddess, from the languid closed eye,</br>Driv'st heavy sleep, the hated kin of death,</br>And active man again</br>Pursues his wonted joys.
The traveller starts, and briskly plies his steps,</br>The ploughman drives his vigorous team afield,</br>The jocund shepherd's care</br>Swift hastens to the plain.
The buskin'd goddess and her fleet-limb'd nymphs</br>O'er the moist lawn swift chase the reeking stag,</br>And cheer the panting hounds,</br>With loud and joyful shout.
To some the dull still hours of night are dear,</br>To me the chearful day, fair queen of morn,</br>O give me oft to view</br>Thy purple-streaming light.</br>
